text:
Christine Folivi: I am 
Christine Folivi.

Darlin Paredes: My name is 
Darlin Paredes.

Christine Folivi: So I was actually born in
West Africa.
I'm from Togo.
And I came here when I was 2 years old.

Darlin Paredes: I was actually born in El
Salvador.
I came here when I was 9.
Christine Folivi: I've always liked science.

I've always gotten good grades in science
basically, from middle school to high school.
Darlin Paredes: In school, it was difficult.

I had no idea what was going on, especially
in third grade.
I had no idea what it is because of the language.

But then, after the years progressed, I was
able to catch up and be the student that gets
good grades.

Christine Folivi: Most people probably think
that physics is harder than chemistry, but
I think it's the other way around.

That was the hardest class I've ever taken
in my life.

I actually had to drop out of physics just
to focus on chemistry, and that's how I got
introduced to this SEED project.

Darlin Paredes: At first, it was kind of
intimidating because you are surrounded by scientists
and they are so knowledgeable.

And then me just
coming in there...
But then also learning their ways, that's pretty nice.
That's really nice.

Andrew Davis: We're always interested in getting
students of all levels of education interested

in what we do here and providing them with
some kind of exposure to the science that

is involved in preservation science: the chemistry,
the physics, the materials science.

I think early exposure to science, early exposure
to the laboratory setting, even if they decide

that preservation science is not for them,
even if they decide that chemistry is not

for them, getting that experience early on,
getting opportunities that perhaps they might

not have had otherwise is maybe the most invaluable
part of the program as I see it.

And I really hope that they take away the
idea they are indeed capable of doing scientific work.

It's not some ivory tower that is closed to
only a certain set of people.

Allison Aldridge: It's a great program because,
it's reallyâ€”I think of it as a seed.
You're planting seeds.

And not every person is going to become a
chemist but they may find that they may do

something related to it, or it helped their
creativity and their critical thinking.
So it's a win-win either way.

It's gonna have helped you become the person
that you are meant to be.
Allison Aldridge: They're go-getters.

They're really curious; they're looking for
opportunities.

Even the ones that come in and say, "I'm not
going to study chemistry; I already know I
want to go into computers," or whatever.

But they still want the opportunities to see
what it's like.

Darlin Paredes: I'm trying to find out which
component of paper affects the decomposition
of the paper.

My typical day, I run my samples, depending
on what I'm working on, depending on what

I'm comparing, I run a specific paper and
try to analyze it afterwards with what I'm

wanting to compare, either the fabric type,
pulp type, or the lignin type.

Christine Folivi: We're basically trying to
figure out ways to know that a tape is degraded
by contact angles or the microscope.

We're trying to figure out ways to know it's
degraded without putting it into expensive
instruments first.
It's a little challenging.

I had to learn to how to be patient with the
research.

Darlin Paredes: I think the challenging part
is rerunning samples because some samples
take a certain amount of time.
Some take a short amount of time.

So if I make a little mistake I have to redo
it and wait til it does it again.

Christine Folivi: I think this is probably
one of my best summers.
It certainly kept me busy.

I spend most of my time here, so I have a
lot of things to tell my parents when I get home.
I actually really enjoy this.

Darlin Paredes: From social media, I think
my friends have been like going to the beach
and all of that.

I think they have had a pretty nice summer,
but I'm okay doing what I'm doing.
I prefer this.

Darlin Paredes: It looks like it was done
pretty easy, but it took so many hours and
I think that it was worth it.

Christine Folivi: It was hard, but the final
product, I love it and I'm going to put it
on my wall at home.

Darlin Paredes: One of the one things that
I will take with me from this experience will

be the ability to be in lab working with a
mentor and actually doing a scientific project.
That was a great experience to have.
Christine Folivi: It feels like I have credibility
and it feels like I have a doctorate when I don't.

So going back to high school is going to be
a little, like a switch.
Andrew Davis: I think the poster session was fantastic.

It felt like any poster session I've been
at with grad students interacting, passing ideas

back and forth, giving each other an appropriately
hard time.

And I think that this would be a fantastic
first stepping stone for them and would hopefully

encourage them when they invariably run up
against difficulties, whether that's technical

difficulties or interpersonal and institutional
difficulties that they can look back and say,

"You know what, I presented my work to the
top echelon scientists in the Washington section

of the American Chemical Society and can stand
toe-to-toe with them.

And if I can do that, I can do whatever else
I want to do."

And so if they don't follow up with chemistry,
good for them, but I'm obviously a little

bit biased, I hope they stick with the chemistry
because I think they're both really good aspiring
chemists and materials scientists.

Andrew Davis: Unfortunately, I had to leave
prior to the awards ceremony and so I was

just sitting on the train heading back to
Baltimore and received a very excited text

from Darlin that she had won the second place
poster.

And that got me just really excited and pleased
and very smiley.
On a commuter train where people don't tend to be very smiley.
Funny timing.

Because as we were talking, I 
felt my phone buzz in my pocket

and I looked, right now 
as I'm opening it up.

And here's a text message 
from Christine.
I swear I did not script this.

"Looking for some advice
on some essays

and personal recommendations
for colleges."
